quiz.title: Unit 8: National Income and Circular Flow (Quiz 6)
quiz.subtitle: 8.6 The Expenditure Approach: C + I + G + (X-M) Calculation (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Economics
quiz.topic: Expenditure Approach, GDP Components, Economic Accounting

questions.question: The expenditure approach to GDP sums:
options: All income earned in the economy
All spending on final goods and services
questions.explanation: The expenditure approach calculates GDP by summing all spending on final goods and services: Y = C + I + G + (X - M).

questions.question: In the formula Y = C + I + G + (X - M), the 'C' represents:
options: Consumer spending on final goods and services
questions.explanation: C stands for personal consumption expenditures - household spending on durable goods, nondurable goods, and services.

questions.question: Investment spending (I) in GDP includes:
options: Business fixed investment, residential investment, and inventory changes
questions.explanation: Investment includes business spending on equipment and structures, residential construction, and changes in business inventories.

questions.question: Government spending (G) in the expenditure approach includes:
options: All government expenditures including transfer payments
Only purchases of goods and services
questions.explanation: G includes government purchases of goods and services but excludes transfer payments like Social Security, which are not payments for current production.

questions.question: Net exports (X - M) represents:
options: Exports minus imports of goods and services
questions.explanation: Net exports equal exports of goods and services minus imports of goods and services. A positive value means trade surplus, negative means trade deficit.

questions.question: Which of the following is counted in consumption (C)?
options: Household purchase of a new car
Business purchase of a delivery truck
questions.explanation: Household purchases of new cars count as consumption of durable goods. Business vehicles are investment, government purchases are G, and exports are X.

questions.question: A company building a new factory would be counted in:
questions.explanation: Construction of factories and business structures is counted as business fixed investment in the I component.

questions.question: If imports exceed exports, net exports will be:
questions.explanation: When imports > exports, (X - M) is negative, meaning the country is consuming more foreign goods than it is selling abroad.

questions.question: Which transaction would be included in investment (I)?
options: A business adding to its inventory
A consumer buying a used car
questions.explanation: Changes in business inventories count as investment. Stock purchases are financial transactions, used goods are not current production, and government roads are G.

questions.question: The largest component of GDP in most economies is typically:
questions.explanation: Consumption usually accounts for 60-70% of GDP in developed economies, making it the largest expenditure component.

questions.question: A negative value for net exports means:
options: The country has a trade surplus
The country has a trade deficit
questions.explanation: Negative net exports (X - M < 0) indicates a trade deficit - the country is importing more goods and services than it is exporting.

questions.question: Which would be counted in government spending (G)?
questions.explanation: Military salaries are payments for current services and count in G. Transfer payments like Social Security and unemployment benefits are excluded from G.

questions.question: If a US consumer buys a car made in Germany, this affects GDP as:
options: Increase in C and decrease in M
Increase in C and increase in M
questions.explanation: The car purchase increases consumption (C) but also increases imports (M), so the net effect on GDP is zero since C and M increase by the same amount.

questions.question: The most volatile component of GDP expenditure is usually:
questions.explanation: Investment spending is typically the most volatile because businesses quickly adjust investment plans based on economic conditions and expectations.

questions.question: A household's purchase of a newly constructed house is counted as:
questions.explanation: New residential construction is counted as investment because it creates capital that will provide housing services over many years.

questions.question: If GDP = $10 trillion, C = $7 trillion, I = $2 trillion, and G = $2 trillion, then net exports must be:
Which of the following is NOT included in investment (I)?
questions.explanation: Purchase of corporate bonds is a financial transaction, not investment in GDP terms. GDP investment refers to physical capital formation.

questions.question: The expenditure approach demonstrates that GDP can be measured by:
options: Following the money spent on final output
Measuring total wealth in the economy
questions.explanation: The expenditure approach tracks all spending on final goods and services, based on the principle that every dollar spent becomes someone's income.

questions.question: A country with high consumption and low investment might experience:
options: Slow economic growth in the long run
No effect on future production capacity
questions.explanation: Low investment means less capital accumulation, which can limit future production capacity and economic growth potential.

questions.question: The expenditure components must sum to GDP because:
options: Every dollar spent on output becomes someone's income
questions.explanation: The fundamental identity arises because every transaction has both a spending side and an income side - what is spent on output becomes income for the factors that produced it.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You thoroughly understand the expenditure approach to GDP and can work with the C + I + G + (X-M) formula confidently.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! You understand the basic components but should practice identifying which transactions belong in each category and solving calculation problems.
scoreMessages.50: A fair start. Focus on: memorizing the expenditure formula, understanding what each component includes, and practicing classification of economic transactions.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Remember the expenditure approach formula: GDP = Consumption + Investment + Government Spending + Net Exports, and learn what types of spending go into each category.
